title: Youthful Manchester United's fight against Liverpool offers some renewed hope for Ole Gunnar Solskjaer
text:
Jose Mourinho, up in the Sky Sports studio from where he would later be seen blowing kisses to the Stretford End who were chanting his name, could not resist a pre-match dig at Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, his successor as Manchester United manager.

“I’m going to try and get a job like Ole has, and speak all the time about the future,” Mourinho ventured, in remarks dripping with sarcasm. “I think it’s a great situation, three year contract - the future, the young players. I think it’s a great job to do in such a giant club.”

Solskjaer’s repeated talk about long-term forecasts has appeared in danger at times of ignoring more immediate perils and for Mourinho who, conscious of the impatience of the big clubs and with a thirst for instant success, has always focused on the here and now over the future, such a strategy might be considered at best a risk, at worst naive.

But while Mourinho invested his faith in experienced heads, often eschewing youth in the process, Solskjaer set his stall out quite clearly in the summer and is banking on a bunch of youngsters to buy him enough time to implement real change at Old Trafford. This was supposed to be the day when Solskjaer’s bubble was well and truly punctured, the day his faith looked horribly misguided.
description: Jose Mourinho, up in the Sky Sports studio from where he would later be seen blowing kisses to the Stretford End who were chanting his name, could not resist a pre-match dig at Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, his successor as Manchester United manager.
